overview: Who can get National Insurance credits and how to apply or when to pay voluntary National Insurance contributions
title: National Insurance credits

table.body:
If you're not paying National Insurance you may be able to get National Insurance credits. 

Credits may help to fill in any gaps in your National Insurance record. This can mean  that you'll still get the full State Pension and other benefits.

Credits are for people in certain circumstances, eg when you're ill or unemployed and claiming benefits or when you don't earn enough to pay National Insurance.
 
There are Class 1 and Class 3 credits. They both pay towards your State Pension but cover different benefits. 


*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Overview

table.body:
The list below shows if you may be able to get National Insurance credits. You may get your credits automatically, but in some cases you'll have to apply for them

Group | Who qualifies | How to get credits  
- | - | -   
Unemployed | You can't be in education or working more than 16 hours a week | You get credits automatically 
Illness, disability, maternity leave | You must be getting one of these: Employment and Support Allowance, Unemployability Supplement or Allowance, Maternity Allowance | You get credits automatically
On maternity, paternity, adoption or sick pay | You must get one of these: Statutory Maternity/Paternity/Adoption Pay, Additional Statutory Paternity Pay, Statutory Sick Pay | Call the helpline to apply for credits - see number below this table
Men approaching 65 | You must live in the UK at least 183 days a year and one of these must apply: you don't work, you don't earn enough to make the 'qualifying year' for the State Pension, you're self employed and have a [Small Earnings Exception Certificate ](/self-employed-national-insurance-rates "Small Earnings Exception Certificate") | You'll get credits automatically 
Parents and carers | One of these must apply: you're a registered carer, you're caring for someone sick or disabled at least 20 hours a week | [Download form CF411A, application for credits (PDF, 56KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/cf411a.pdf "Download CF411A, parents and carers application for credits (PDF, 56KB)"){:rel="external"} 
Parents and carers | One of these must apply: you're on Carer's Allowance, Income Support or getting Child Benefit for a child under 12 | You get credits automatically
On a government approved private training course | All of these must apply: you're over 18, your course is government approved and no longer than 1 year | Write to: HMRC, National Insurance Contributions and Employers Office, Benton Park View, Newcastle upon Tyne, NE98 1ZZ 
On a government sponsored training course | Anyone | You get credits automatically
Working Tax Credit | You must get Working Tax Credit and have a [Small Earnings Exception certificate](/self-employed-national-insurance-rates "Small Earnings Exception") if self-employed | You get credits automatically
Partners of members in Armed Forces | You must be married or a civil partner and going with your partner on an  overseas posting | [Download form MODCA1, application for credits (PDF, 80KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/modca1.pdf "Download Application form MODCA1, application for credits" (PDF, 80KB)"){:rel="external"}
On jury service | You must have attended court. If you're self-employed, you can't get credits  | Call the helpline 
Wrongly imprisoned | Your conviction must have been quashed by the Court of Appeal (or the Court of Criminal Appeal in Scotland) | Call the helpline 


From the 2011 to 2012 tax year there are new credits for people aged 16 and over who care for a child under 12. You have to be under State Pension age to qualify. You don't need to do anything yet if you want to apply.

If you have any questions about National Insurance credits, call the helpline:

$C
**National Insurance Helpline**

Telephone: 0845 302 1479  
Textphone: 0845 915 3296  
Monday to Friday, 8am to 8pm  
Saturday, 8am to 4pm
$C

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
*[NI]: National Insurance
table.title: Eligibility

table.body:
You usually don't get National Insurance credits if you're:

- employed and paying Class 1 contributions 
- self-employed and paying Class 2 contributions
- a married woman paying reduced Class 1 under the [Married Woman's Reduced Rate Election](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ni/reducedrate/marriedwomen.htm "Married Woman's Reduced Rate Election"){:rel="external"} before 1977 


If you're a women paying the reduced Class 1 rate you still get credits if:  

- you're a widow 
- you're looking after someone who's sick or disabled 
- you've been wrongly imprisoned

If you have any questions about National Insurance credits, call the helpline:

$C
**National Insurance Helpline**  
Telephone: 0845 302 1479  
Textphone: 0845 915 3296  
Monday to Friday, 8am to 8pm  
Saturday, 8am to 4pm
$C
table.title: Who can't get credits

table.body:
If you were eligible for credits at any time you can check if they're on your National Insurance record:

- [apply for a National Insurance statement](https://online.hmrc.gov.uk/shortforms/form/NIStatement?dept-name=&sub-dept-name=&location=40&origin=http://www.hmrc.gov.uk "Apply for a National Insurance statement"){:rel="external"} from HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)
- call the National Insurance Helpline or write to HMRC:

$C
**National Insurance Helpline**

Telephone: 0845 302 1479  
Textphone: 0845 915 3296  
Monday to Friday 8am to 8pm  
Saturday 8am to 4pm
$C

$A
HM Revenue & Customs
Individuals Caseworker
Benton Park View
Newcastle upon Tyne
NE98 1ZZ
$A

If you live abroad [contact HMRC.](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kb5/hmrc/contactus/view.page?record=OLul3tPejl4 "Contact HMRC"){:rel="external"}
